Key Arguments: The legislation poses a threat to free expression, self-determination, freedom of thought, conscience, and religion.
The Bill creates a monopoly over communication by allowing a government-appointed agency to police misinformation and disinformation.
The Bill exempts government content from scrutiny, which could lead to biased enforcement.
The definition of misinformation and disinformation is vague and subjective, leading to potential misuse.
The Bill could lead to censorship and suppression of minority opinions and open debate.
Civil penalties under the Bill could be unjustly imposed due to the lower standard of proof required.
The Bill could lead to a slippery slope towards totalitarianism by eroding individual freedoms.
Notable Quotes: This Bill poses a threat to the rights of free expression, self-determination, freedom of thought, conscience and religion.
The Bill facilitates the scrutiny and censorship of information not just pertaining to the touted issues of public health but also foreign policy and by extension opinions from political parties.
The very concept of defining misinformation and disinformation is an impossibility, not to mention impractical.
The intention of this proposed legislation is to extinguish individual responsibility, in effect to dumb us down and steer us to a predetermined conclusion, like lambs to slaughter.
